bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, February 23, 1953

div1.p: Tate believes that Warner has tried to take credit that belongs to others in the yellow fever experiments. He regrets that Pinto and Stark were not mentioned at the Camp Lazear dedication.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, February 23, 1953
div1.opener:
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley, 3, California
February 23, 1953
Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench;
div1.p:
I received a letter recently from General Truby, telling
me of the dedication of Camp Lazear. In it he noted that
all whom he had given credit to in his book were honored
there, except Miss Warner, whom he did not remember.

I replying I stated that of course he had given her no
mention as having helped the Y.F. experiments, for although
she was there at the time he was head of the hospital he
knew her only as Head Nurse of the female nurse corps.

I told him that I had known her quite well and met her often
when talking to Nurse Holmes, of the receiving ward, as
she and the latter were great friends. I never heard of
her as being connected with the real experiments. She may
have been around Lazear and Carroll when they were sick;-
I don't know. I quoted Truby extracts from an address she
had made to the Shelby County Med. Asso.

Truby asked me if I would send this “printed matter” to
you and to tell you it was sent at his request. It is not
printed matter, as he supposed, but a copy typed by Nurse
Warner or at her direction. You may have probably seen
it before, as she evidently had lots of copies, but, any-
way, I send it as Truby requested. I have read for more
incredible articles written by her relating to her service
in Cuba. - A Baroness Munchausen!

There is nothing vindicitive in anything I say against
this nurse, even though she did try to take credit that
belonged to others, and I am sure Gen. Truby has no such
feelings. I believe she should simply be dropped from any
further publications realting to the Y.F. experiments.

After the ceremonies at Camp Lazear I looked eagerly though
my magazines, “Life,” and many others, thinking that there
would surely be some mention of such a Cuban-American
event, but failed to find anything about it. I know there
are lots of old vets who served at Col. Bks. who would be
interested in it, so I used my old reportorial instincts
and patched up what hints I could secure and sent a small
take to the National Tribune, (the veteran's paper). Since
receipt of Truby's letter, I find that I hit it close, in
a very brief manner. I sent you a clipping, but I doubt
you received it.

One other thing: General Truby has asked me about a John
Peter Barnstad of the H. Corps at Col. Bks. I handled all
(Tate-Hench-2)
the pay rolls, muster rolls, sick & wounded repports and
all army orders there from Sept. 1900 to August 1901, and
knew all Corps Men there personally. During that period
I can remember no man there of that name.

Regret to learn from General Truby that no mention was made
of Dr. Pinto. He was C.O. there when I arrived from Pinar
del Rio just befor Truby took over. He took the preliminary
tests with mosquitoes before Lazear found out how the birds
really worked. And no -mention of Capt. Stark! Excuse
this long letter, but I don't know how to make it shorter.
div1.closer: Sincerely & Cordially Yours, Paul L. Tate (1 encl.)
